newsitem.title: SPAIN: MOTORCYCLING-DOOHAN CHAMPION AS CHECA PLEASES THE FANS.
newsitem.headline: MOTORCYCLING-DOOHAN CHAMPION AS CHECA PLEASES THE FANS.

text.p: Australia's Michael Doohan took his third consecutive 500cc world championship after finishing second behind local man Carlos Checa in the Grand Prix of Catalonia on Sunday.
"It's unbelievable, at the beginning of the year I just didn't think this was possible" said Doohan.
For Checa, a local man, it was the first win of a promising career and some compensation after falling whilst leading last year's race.
He received the race trophy from King Juan Carlos, himself a keen motorcycle enthusiast.
Doohan said that Checa's move had helped him. "Checa took the lead and that was good -- it took the pressure off meaning I could finish lower down."
Doohan, who had only needed to finish second to ensure the title, fulfilled his pre-race promise of sticking to Alex Criville, the only rider who could catch the Australian in the overall standings.
Italy's Luca Cadalora was first off the grid, but was unable to contain Checa who took the lead on the third lap and never looked back.
Behind him Criville and Doohan were involved in an exciting battle that saw the rival Honda men exchange places nine times.
Although Doohan could have allowed Criville to take second and himself finish fourth, the Australian pulled out the stops to beat the Spaniard by just 0.049 seconds.
It was a fitting climax to a season dominated by the rivalry, and occasional conflict, between the two.
With two races remaining Criville's performance guaranteed him second place in the championship, the best classification ever obtained by a Spaniard.
"It would have been nice to win at home, but Checa went really well," said Criville.

Earlier in the day Max Biaggi boosted his own chances of retaining the 250cc world title after recovering from a mistake at the first bend to surge past Frenchman Olivier Jacque to his eighth win of the season.
Biaggi, who did `wheelies' around much of the last lap and then threw his helmet to fans, extends his championship lead over Germany's Ralf Waldmann to 21 points.

Tomomi Manako celebrated his first win in the 125cc category in more controversial fashion -- the Japanese rider grasped his right arm at the elbow with the left and repeatedly raised a finger in what appeared to be a traditional Latin insult.
"I didn't know what it meant, I was saying `number one'" said a smiling Manako afterwards.
The win moved Manako into contention in the 125 cc championship, leaving him just one point behind second-placed rider Masaki Tokudome, a faller at the first bend.
Leading the championship a further 14 points ahead is another Japanese rider, Haruchika Aoki, who finished fifth.
